items.content: Read the introduction on page 30 and use page 154.

content.body: In the Middle East and North Africa, lived in close to . They were able to produce so much food that some could in art, trade, religion, writing or warfare. Eventually the villages grew to become the first .

Which part of the introduction match with the characteristic: the agricultural revolution?

In the Middle East and North Africa, farmers lived in villages close to rivers. They were able to produce so much food that some could specialise in art, trade, religion, writing or warfare. Eventually the villages grew to become the first cities.

Which part of the introduction match with the characteristic: the first urban communities?

In the Middle East and North Africa, farmers lived in villages close to rivers. They were able to produce so much food that some could specialise in art, trade, religion, writing or warfare. Eventually the villages grew to become the first cities.

items.content: Read the box with key-words on page 30.

Which words are mentioned in the boxes at page 30?

Prehistory - Mesopatamia - Irrigation - Nomads - Civilisation - Agriculture - Agricultural surplus - Craftsmen - Culture - Bartering - Martkets - Pharaoh - Archaeologist - Sources - Fertile Crescent

When farmers produce more food than they can eat

prompt.body: Put the events in the right (chronological) order:

content.body: The farmers will seed in the fertile ground.
The river flews back, leaving behind fertile soil and water in the canals
Then the water rises and covers the riverbanks
Farmers dug canals before the water rises
The water of the river is low
Finally, the crops can be harvested.

items.content: Check the parts about An abundance of food and Villages become cities.

content.body: With help of the , farmers were able to produce more then they could ever eat. The , the extra food they produced, meant that some farmers could do other jobs. In other words: people could themselves in doing one task. Some became , like a carpenter or a potter. That means that they ware making products with their hands and with help of simple . At some occasions, farmers were buying their goods with grain. We call that .

prompt.body: Put the events in the right chronological order.

content.body: Some of these craftsmen started to live in cities; this is how agricultural-urban societies arose.
The craftsmen and farmers traded traded there wares at the markets for foods.
These people became craftsmen and were specialised in making products with their hands.
Because if this agricultural surplus some people could specialise.
The river overflowed and left fertile silt. Farmers grew crops here.
Some farmers learned that they could dig small canals to make more land fertile.
Because of irrigation and flood, farmers grew more food than they could eat.

items.content: Read the last paragraph about Sumer and Egypt: the first civilisations and the Essence.

content.body:
Fill in the gaps. Use the past simple.

Archaeologists (to find) the remains of the Sumerian and Egyptian civilisations during excavations in the past. But since then also historians can do research, both highly developed cultures (to know) how to write. The prehistory (to end) around 3,000 BC.

The first civilisations (to start) along rivers in the area we call the Ferttile Crescent. There farmers (to learn) how to use the water from the rivers Euphrates, Tigris and the Nile. They (to build) irrgation-systems and (to produce) more food than they (to need). Therefore some farmers (to choose) to do other jobs. They (to specialise) themselves. They (to become), for example, smith or carpenter and (to sell) their products at markets. There merchants and craftsmen (to gather) together and cities (to arise), the first urban communities.

At the same moment kings (to begin) to increase their power. They (to claim) to be gods and (to be) commanders of the armies. A king also (to have) to write down his rules, the laws, by scribes. People who (to commit) a crime (to receive) a severe punihsment from the king's judges. The people (to pay) taxes which (to make) all this possible.
